Post.title: 海洋科学导论
Post._content:
## Overview

-   70.8% of Earth covered by ocean
    
-   97.5% of surface water
    
-   Interconnnected global ocean
    
    ![Pasted image 20250927143743](https://picgo-1385161956.cos.ap-shanghai.myqcloud.com/imgs/Pasted%20image%2020250927143743.png)

### Principal Oceans

-   Pacific Ocean - Largest.deepest
    
-   Atlantic Ocean - Second largest
    
-   Indian Ocean - Mainly in Southern Hemisphere
    
-   Arctic Ocean - Smallest,shallowes,Northern Hemisphere $$海大 \ne 水多$$
    

## The water molecule

### polar molecule

lead to these properties:

-   Good dissolving ability
    
-   Hydrogen Bonds
    
-   Cohesion
    
-   Adhesion
    
-   High heat Capacity
    

## Physical properties of water and seawater

### High heat capacity

-   temerature mediation
    
-   heat redistribution
    
-   weather/climate
    
    ![Pasted image 20250927144857](https://picgo-1385161956.cos.ap-shanghai.myqcloud.com/imgs/Pasted%20image%2020250927144857.png)

### Latent Heat

![Pasted image 20250927145148](https://picgo-1385161956.cos.ap-shanghai.myqcloud.com/imgs/Pasted%20image%2020250927145148.png)

-   Latent Heat of Fusion: Amount of heat needed to change from a solid to a liquid
    
-   Latent Heat of Vaporization：Amount of heat needed to change from a liquid to a vapor
    
    ![Pasted image 20250927145539](https://picgo-1385161956.cos.ap-shanghai.myqcloud.com/imgs/Pasted%20image%2020250927145539.png)
    
    •Latent heat of vaporization (evaporation) is far greater than latent heat of fusion (melting). •All of the H bonds between $H_{2}O$molecules must be broken to form vapor ==Water also helps moderate global temperatures by redistributing equatorial heat poleward==
    

### Viscosity

-   Definition:The resistance of fluid to flow
    
-   Water:low viscosity
    
-   T increases, viscosity lowers -- Surface water at equator is warmer and less viscous than Arctic
    

### Surface Tension

-   Definition:Lateral and downward attraction between individual molecules
    
-   Creates a strong boundary at surface
    
-   ↑ salt = ↑ surface tension,↓ H2O temp = ↑ surface tension
    

### Compressibility

-   Definition:Substance’s ability to undergo volume changes
    
-   Water:very slight compressibility -- almost incompressible
    

### Density

$$\rho = \rho(T,S,p)$$

-   T(Temperature) water becomes less dense when it freezes
    
    ![Pasted image 20250927151801](https://picgo-1385161956.cos.ap-shanghai.myqcloud.com/imgs/Pasted%20image%2020250927151801.png)
-   S(Salinity) Adding salts increases density decrease freezing point,increase boiling point
    
    ![Pasted image 20250927151835](https://picgo-1385161956.cos.ap-shanghai.myqcloud.com/imgs/Pasted%20image%2020250927151835.png)
-   p(Pressure) changes in pressure are mostly ignored by physical properties of water - seawater is nearly incompressible,but **Dynamically important**.--In situ density & potential density
    

## Chemical properties of seawater

### Salinity

-   Definition:the total quantity of dissolved inorganic solids in water.
    
-   measured in g/kg (ppt = parts per thousand)
    
-   35‰ on average for seawater
    
-   ==Ocean salinities vary in Space and Time==

> Affect salinity:

-   evaporation
    
-   precipitation
    
-   runoff
    
-   freezing
    
-   melting
    

> Components

-   3.5% (by weight) dissolved mineral substances: –Cl- (55%) –Na+ (30.6%) –SO42-(7.7%) –Mg+ (3.7%) –Ca2+ (1.2%) –K +(1.1%) –HCO3-(<1%) –Minor constituents (0.7%) Sr, Br, & C •Minor/trace elements important to living things
    
    ![Pasted image 20250927153804](https://picgo-1385161956.cos.ap-shanghai.myqcloud.com/imgs/Pasted%20image%2020250927153804.png)

### The ocean is in chemical equilibrium(化学平衡)

\==Salinity is not increasing==(rate of addition ~ rate of removal)

#### Where do the ocean's salt come from

-   Positive ions: weathering and erosion
    
-   Negative ions: gases from volcanic eruptions
    
-   Hydrothermal activity supply and remove salt from the deep ocean
    

#### Why is the ocean's salt constant

-   **Input**:rivers,volcanic activity,ground water,hydrothermal vents and cold spirings,and the decay of once-living organisms
    
-   **Output**:sea spray,uptake by living organisms,incorporation into sediments,and ultimately by subduction
    

#### **Principle of constant proportions**

> The percentage of various salts in seawater is the same in samples from many places, regardless how salty the water is.

Cl- is abundant and always accounts for 55% of dissolved salts, the following formula is used to determine salinity: $$Salinity\\ in\\ ‰ = 1.80655 × Chlorinity\\ in \\ ‰$$ For observation, conductivity （电导率）is measured first, and then calculate the corresponding salinity.

### Gases in the seawater

-   **Photosynthesis**:$CO_{2}\to O_{2}$
    
-   **Respiration**:$O_{2}\to CO_{2}$
    
    ![Pasted image 20250927155820](https://picgo-1385161956.cos.ap-shanghai.myqcloud.com/imgs/Pasted%20image%2020250927155820.png)
    
    Where do they comes from?
    

### PH,Carbonate Buffer

![Pasted image 20250927160149](https://picgo-1385161956.cos.ap-shanghai.myqcloud.com/imgs/Pasted%20image%2020250927160149.png)![Pasted image 20250927160156](https://picgo-1385161956.cos.ap-shanghai.myqcloud.com/imgs/Pasted%20image%2020250927160156.png)

-   Seawater:**Basic**,pH 7.5 - 8.5
    
-   Average pH = 7.8
    
-   pH relatively constant due to buffering action of$CO_{2}$
    
-   **Buffer** = substance that prevents sudden or large changes in the acidity or alkalinity of a solution
    
-   Important for biological processes
    
-   pH inversely proportional to the concentration of $CO_{2}$(pH和二氧化碳浓度反比)
    

## Structures of the ocean

## Light and sound in the ocean

## Sea ice

Post.content:
Overview

  • 70.8% of Earth covered by ocean

  • 97.5% of surface water

  • Interconnnected global ocean

Principal Oceans

  • Pacific Ocean - Largest.deepest

  • Atlantic Ocean - Second largest

  • Indian Ocean - Mainly in Southern Hemisphere

  • Arctic Ocean - Smallest,shallowes,Northern Hemisphere $$海大 \ne 水多$$

The water molecule

polar molecule

lead to these properties:

  • Good dissolving ability

  • Hydrogen Bonds

  • Cohesion

  • Adhesion

  • High heat Capacity

Physical properties of water and seawater

High heat capacity

  • temerature mediation

  • heat redistribution

  • weather/climate

Latent Heat

  • Latent Heat of Fusion: Amount of heat needed to change from a solid to a liquid

  • Latent Heat of Vaporization：Amount of heat needed to change from a liquid to a vapor

    •Latent heat of vaporization (evaporation) is far greater than latent heat of fusion (melting). •All of the H bonds between $H_{2}O$molecules must be broken to form vapor ==Water also helps moderate global temperatures by redistributing equatorial heat poleward==

Viscosity

  • Definition:The resistance of fluid to flow

  • Water:low viscosity

  • T increases, viscosity lowers – Surface water at equator is warmer and less viscous than Arctic

Surface Tension

  • Definition:Lateral and downward attraction between individual molecules

  • Creates a strong boundary at surface

  • ↑ salt = ↑ surface tension,↓ H2O temp = ↑ surface tension

Compressibility

  • Definition:Substance’s ability to undergo volume changes

  • Water:very slight compressibility – almost incompressible

Density

$$\rho = \rho(T,S,p)$$

  • T(Temperature) water becomes less dense when it freezes

  • S(Salinity) Adding salts increases density decrease freezing point,increase boiling point

  • p(Pressure) changes in pressure are mostly ignored by physical properties of water - seawater is nearly incompressible,but Dynamically important.–In situ density & potential density

Chemical properties of seawater

Salinity

  • Definition:the total quantity of dissolved inorganic solids in water.

  • measured in g/kg (ppt = parts per thousand)

  • 35‰ on average for seawater

  • ==Ocean salinities vary in Space and Time==

Affect salinity:

  • evaporation

  • precipitation

  • runoff

  • freezing

  • melting

Components

  • 3.5% (by weight) dissolved mineral substances: –Cl- (55%) –Na+ (30.6%) –SO42-(7.7%) –Mg+ (3.7%) –Ca2+ (1.2%) –K +(1.1%) –HCO3-(<1%) –Minor constituents (0.7%) Sr, Br, & C •Minor/trace elements important to living things

The ocean is in chemical equilibrium(化学平衡)

==Salinity is not increasing==(rate of addition ~ rate of removal)

Where do the ocean’s salt come from

  • Positive ions: weathering and erosion

  • Negative ions: gases from volcanic eruptions

  • Hydrothermal activity supply and remove salt from the deep ocean

Why is the ocean’s salt constant

  • Input:rivers,volcanic activity,ground water,hydrothermal vents and cold spirings,and the decay of once-living organisms

  • Output:sea spray,uptake by living organisms,incorporation into sediments,and ultimately by subduction

Principle of constant proportions

The percentage of various salts in seawater is the same in samples from many places, regardless how salty the water is.

Cl- is abundant and always accounts for 55% of dissolved salts, the following formula is used to determine salinity: $$Salinity\ in\ ‰ = 1.80655 × Chlorinity\ in \ ‰$$ For observation, conductivity （电导率）is measured first, and then calculate the corresponding salinity.

Gases in the seawater

  • Photosynthesis:$CO_{2}\to O_{2}$

  • Respiration:$O_{2}\to CO_{2}$

    Where do they comes from?

PH,Carbonate Buffer

  • Seawater:Basic,pH 7.5 - 8.5

  • Average pH = 7.8

  • pH relatively constant due to buffering action of$CO_{2}$

  • Buffer = substance that prevents sudden or large changes in the acidity or alkalinity of a solution

  • Important for biological processes

  • pH inversely proportional to the concentration of $CO_{2}$(pH和二氧化碳浓度反比)

Structures of the ocean

Light and sound in the ocean

Sea ice
